raw_text:
Beckham rules out management move
 
 Real Madrid midfielder David Beckham has no plans to become a manager when his playing career is over.
 
 "I am not interested in being a coach but I would like to have football schools," the England captain said on television station Canal Plus. "I have wanted to do that since I went to the Bobby Charlton school. I'm going to open one in London and one in LA. "My second passion is charity work - I am an ambassador for Unicef and it gives me great pride." But Beckham revealed that his immediate priority was winning the Spanish league title with Real Madrid.
 
 Real slipped to 13 points behind leaders Barcelona with a 1-0 defeat at the hands of Sevilla on Wednesday. Beckham admitted: "It's disappointing and frustrating to see the results, considering the team we have. "I would really like to win La Liga with Real Madrid - I have been here two years and we still have not done it." In a wide-ranging interview, Beckham also revealed that his sending-off against Argentina - and the resulting media storm - had been the most significant moment in his career. Asked for his worst memory, he said: "To be sent off against Argentina - it was not for the sending-off but for what happened afterwards. "I was lucky because I had a manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, who supported me and a strong family behind me but I believe that changed me. "I believe it changed me for the better."
llama3.2:1b: David Beckham has stated he will not become a manager after his playing career is over, and plans to open two football schools in London and Los Angeles instead.
He also expressed disappointment with Real Madrid's recent performance, admitting they have not won La Liga despite being 13 points behind leaders Barcelona.
Additionally, Beckham discussed the media storm surrounding his sending-off against Argentina as the most significant moment in his career.
llama3.2:3b: David Beckham rules out becoming a football manager after his playing career ends, stating he wants to open football schools in London and LA, while prioritizing winning La Liga with Real Madrid and continuing his charity work as an Unicef ambassador.

He will open football schools in London and Los Angeles and wants to continue charity work with Unicef.
He is disappointed with Real Madrid's current performance in La Liga but hopes to win the title.
Beckham admits that his red card against Argentina was a turning point in his career.

He plans to set up football schools in London and LA with his second passion, charity work.
Despite being one of the most popular players in England, he says his immediate priority is winning the Spanish league title.
He revealed that sending off for Argentina during an important game was a significant moment in his career.
Beckham believes it changed him into a better player.

He expressed interest in opening football schools and becoming an ambassador for charities, but his immediate priority remains winning La Liga with Real Madrid.

Beckham also highlights his charitable work with Unicef as one of his passions.
Currently focused on securing Real Madrid's La Liga title, he criticizes the team’s recent results.
Beckham recalls being sent off against Argentina as a significant moment, citing it for its aftermath rather than the sending-off itself.
He believes this experience shaped him positively.
opencoder:1.5b: The text highlights Beckham's decision to leave his previous career after becoming managerless as he showcased his resilience and determination in defeating the Spanish champions Sevilla on Tuesday.
Despite his defeat, he also managed to secure a win at La Liga with Real Madrid, highlighting his passion for football and his goal of winning a major title.

Despite this, winning the Spanish league title with Real Madrid remains his top priority.
Following a 1-0 defeat to Sevilla, which increased their points gap to Barcelona by 13, Beckham expressed frustration with the team's performance and results.

Beckham credits Sir Alex Ferguson and his family for helping him grow from that incident positively.
